body_html:
Hi,

As a matter of fact, it appears that I had the same use case than albertz

  • variables created and stored in one place,
  • various operations defined later and if possible in the same scope than the variables.

I ended up independently to the same conclusion that the scope object had to be stored in the same place than the variables.

It looks like it's not the right way to work with tensorflow variables and so I wonder if you could point me to some guidelines/good practices to structure models. [I'm currently following the practices described here: https://danijar.com/structuring-your-tensorflow-models/, but it doesn't work so well as mentioned above when you want to use the same scope for your operations).

Thx!

Hi,

As a matter of fact, it appears that I had the same use case than albertz 
- variables created and stored in one place,
- various operations defined later and if possible in the same scope than the variables.

I ended up independently to the same conclusion that the scope object had to be stored in the same place than the variables.

It looks like it's not the right way to work with tensorflow variables and so I wonder if you could point me to some guidelines/good practices to structure models. [I'm currently following the practices described here: https://danijar.com/structuring-your-tensorflow-models/, but it doesn't work so well as mentioned above when you want to use the same scope for your operations).

Thx!
